These results show that the presence of a high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler, for example, graphite, obtains the observed synergetic effects.
Example 5

[0148] Similar to the process of Example 1, HDPE (Hostalen GC-7260, Basell), MgO (Maglite DE (agglomerates of sub-μιη particles), Promecome), BN (Coolflow CF300 (platelets/agglomerates, D50 = 15-25 μιη), Momentive Performance Materials) and Graphite (Thermocarb TC300 (platelet with D90 ~ 200 μιη), Asbury Graphite) were formulated into a composition in the proportions set forth below in Table 5 and the through-plane thermal conductivity of the sample compositions was measured according to ASTM E1461. The results are set forth in Table 5 and Figure 5.
Table 5

[0149] Table 5 and Figure 5 show the thermal conductivities of thermally conductive composites containing 15 vol% graphite and a total filler content of 50 vol%, where the MgO and BN volume contents vary. This means that the total volume content of filler is constant at 50 vol% and that the relative MgO and BN contents are varied from 35 vol% MgO (= 0 vol% BN) to 0 vol% MgO (= 35 vol% BN).

[0150] Run 17 shows that the composite containing only MgO and graphite has a relatively low thermal conductivity. Upon partial replacement of the low thermally conductive MgO by the high thermally conductive BN, one would expect a linear increase in the thermal conductivity of the composite, with a maximum thermal conductivity at 0 vol% MgO and 35 vol% BN. However, an unexpected and significant increase of the thermal conductivity is already achieved by replacing a small amount of the MgO with BN, as shown by run 18. In fact, the composite of run 18 shows a thermal conductivity that is as high as the thermal conductivity of the composites containing graphite and a high BN content (runs 19 and 20). Similar to Example 1, these results indicate the presence of a synergetic effect of the three different fillers in these compositions and show that low thermally conductive fillers like MgO can be used to produce composites with a high thermal conductivity or, in other words, large amounts of the high thermally conductive filler can be replaced by a low thermally conductive filler while retaining the thermal conductivity of the composite.
Comparative Example 6

[0151] Similar to the process of Example 1, HDPE (Hostalen GC-7260, Basell), CaC03 (Millicarb (D50 -2.5 μιη), Omya), BN (Coolflow CF300 (platelets/agglomerates, D50 = 15-25 μιη), Momentive Performance Materials) and Graphite (Thermocarb TC300 (platelet with D90 ~ 200 μηι), Asbury Graphite) were formulated into a composition in the proportions set forth below in Table 6 and the through-plane thermal conductivity of the sample compositions was measured according to ASTM E1461. The results are set forth in Table 6 and Figure 6.
Table 6

[0152] Table 6 and Figure 6 show the thermal conductivities of thermally conductive composites containing 15 vol% graphite and a total filler content of 50 vol%, where the CaC03 and BN volume contents vary. This means that the total volume content of filler is constant at 50 vol% and that the relative CaC03 and BN contents are varied from 35 vol% CaC03 (= 0 vol% BN) to 0 vol% CaC03 (= 35 vol% BN). CaC03 belongs to the group of thermally insulative fillers, since it has an intrinsic thermal conductivity below 10 W/mK.

[0153] Run 21 shows that the composite containing only CaC03 and graphite has a relatively low thermal conductivity. In contrast to the results presented in Examples 1, 3, and 5, the partial replacement of CaC03 by BN in the presence of 15 vol% graphite only leads to a linear increase in thermal conductivity (runs 22-24). These results show that the

advantageous effects of the three-component system described herein are not observed when using a thermally insulative filler in place of the low thermally conductive filler.
[0154] In one embodiment, a composition comprises a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer; b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity of from 10 to 30 W/mK; from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; and d. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; wherein the composition is characterized by: i. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK; and ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm.

[0155] In one embodiment, the composition comprises a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer; b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from ZnS, CaO, MgO, ZnO, Ti02, or a combination thereof; c. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; and d. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; wherein the composition is characterized by: i. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK; and ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm.

[0156] In one embodiment, the composition comprises a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer; b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from ZnS, CaO, MgO, ZnO, Ti02, or a combination thereof; c. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from aluminum nitride, boron nitride, magnesium silicon nitride, silicon carbide, ceramic-coated graphite, or a combination thereof; and d. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; wherein the composition is characterized by: i. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK; and ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm.

[0157] In one embodiment, the composition comprises a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer; b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from ZnS, CaO, MgO, ZnO, Ti02, or a combination thereof; c. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from aluminum nitride, boron nitride, magnesium silicon nitride, silicon carbide, ceramic-coated graphite, or a combination thereof; and d. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive,
electrically conductive filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK, wherein the high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler comprises graphite, expanded graphite, graphene, a carbon fiber, a carbon nanotube, graphitized carbon black, or a combination thereof; wherein the composition is characterized by: i. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK; and ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm

[0158] In another embodiment, the composition comprises a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer selected from polyamide, polyester, polyethylene, ethylene based copolymer, polypropylene, polyphenylene sulfide, or a combination thereof; b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler selected from ZnS, MgO, Ί1Ο2, or a combination thereof; c. from 2 to 15 vol% of boron nitride; and d. from 2 to 15 vol% of graphite. In one embodiment, the composition is characterized by: i. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK; and ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm.

[0159] Throughout this application, various publications are referenced. The disclosures of these publications in their entireties are hereby incorporated by reference into this application in order to more fully describe the compounds, compositions and methods described herein.

[0160] Various modifications and variations can be made to the compounds, compositions and methods described herein. Other aspects of the compounds, compositions and methods described herein will be apparent from consideration of the specification and practice of the compounds, compositions and methods disclosed herein. It is intended that the specification and examples be considered as exemplary.

claim.claim-text: 1. A composition comprising:
a. from 35 to 80 vol% of a thermoplastic polymer;
b. from 5 to 45 vol% of a low thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity of from 10 to 30 W/mK;
c. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK; and
d. from 2 to 15 vol% of a high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler with an intrinsic thermal conductivity greater than or equal to 50 W/mK;
wherein the composition is characterized by:
1. a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK;
ii. a volume resistivity of at least 10 Ohm.cm.

2. The composition of claim 1, wherein the thermoplastic polymer comprises a polyamide, polyester, polyethylene and ethylene based copolymer, polypropylene, polyphenylene sulfide, polyetheretherketone, polycarbonate, polyetherimide, or a combination thereof.
3. The composition of claim 1 or claim 2, wherein the thermoplastic polymer comprises a polyamide, polyester, polyethylene and ethylene based copolymer,
polypropylene, polyphenylene sulfide, or a combination thereof.
4. The composition of any one of claims 1-3, wherein the low thermally conductive filler comprises ZnS, CaO, MgO, ZnO, Ti02, or a combination thereof.
5. The composition of any one of claims 1-4, wherein the low thermally conductive filler comprises ZnS, Ti02, MgO, or a combination thereof.

6. The composition of any one of claims 1-5, wherein the high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler comprises AIN (aluminum nitride), BN (boron nitride), MgSiN2 (magnesium silicon nitride), SiC (silicon carbide), ceramic-coated graphite, or a combination thereof.
7. The composition of any one of claims 1-6, wherein the high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler comprises boron nitride, silicon carbide, or a combination thereof.

8. The composition of any one of claims 1-7, wherein the high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler comprises graphite, expanded graphite, graphene, a carbon fiber, a carbon nanotube, graphitized carbon black, or a combination thereof.
9. The composition of any one of claims 1-8, wherein the high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler comprises graphite, expanded graphite, or a combination thereof.
10. The composition of any one of claims 1-9, wherein the thermoplastic polymer comprises a polyamide, polyester, polyethylene and ethylene based copolymer,

polypropylene, polyphenylene sulfide, or a combination thereof; the low thermally conductive filler comprises, ZnS, Ti02, MgO, or a combination thereof; the high thermally conductive, electrically insulative filler comprises boron nitride; and the high thermally conductive, electrically conductive filler comprises graphite.
11. An article formed from the composition of any one of claims 1-10.
12. The article of claim 11, wherein the article is a molded article.

13. A method of using a thermoplastic polymer composition in a high thermal conductivity application comprising contacting the thermoplastic polymer composition of any preceding claims 1-10 with an elevated external temperature for a sustained time, wherein the thermoplastic polymer composition is used in an application requiring the composition to have (1) a thermal conductivity of at least 1.0 W/mK, and (2) a volume resistivity of at least 107 Ohm.cm.
14. The method of claim 13, wherein the polymer composition is in the form of an article.
15. The method of claim 14, wherein the article is a molded article.
